description.narrative: Mosul Dam remains in a high-risk condition to the lives Experts express concerns about the likelihood of collapse and have called for sustained actions on emergency response and preparedness for the vulnerable communities in the downstream.

participating-org.narrative: UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1) # of trainings (national and governorate-level) completed. 2)# of (governorate) Emergency Alert and Communication System (EACS) developed. 3) # of governorate-level Civil Defence (CD) Committees setup 4) Dam risk advocacy and communication strategy developed. 5)# of hospitals supported for emergency preparedness. 6) # of schools supported for emergency preparedness. 7)# of community volunteers recruited (gender disaggregated) for the Community Early Warning and Evacuation Network. 8) Safety standards established. 9) # of priority Critical Infrastructure (CI) sectors mapped.

comment.narrative: 1)1 Training ( for Mosul Dam Managers) -2018 2) 0 (2018) 3) 0 (2018) 4) Strategy not in place (2018) 5) 10 hospitals supported (2018) 6) 20 schools (2018) 7) 0 (2018) 8) Safety standard not established 9) 0 sectors mapped (2018)

1) 3 Trainings on local and emergency officials trained on response and preparedness. 2) 0 Emergency Alert and Communication System (EACS) 3) Governorate-level Civil Defence (CD) Committees 4) Dam risk advocacy and communication strategy developed 5) 5 Hospitals supported with hospital‐based simulations and drills. 6) 50 Schools supported with school‐based simulations and drills. 7) 100 volunteers (gender disaggregated) trained for the Community Early Warning and Evacuation Network. 8) 1 Standards Manual developped. 9) 10 Critical Infrastructure sectors mapped.

- Throughout 2019, Baghdad and Salahuddin Governorates, supported by UNDP, made significant progress in raising awareness among officials, establishing priority structures at different levels of administration, and setting up mechanisms. By November 2019, all 22 Districts of Baghdad and Salahuddin Governorates had established CDMCs. At the district level, CDMCs achieved the following: 1) the committees are functional, 2) leadership roles are defined, 3) the composition of membership is specified, 4) frequency of meetings set, and 5) planning process of prioritization initiated. CDMCs at the high-risk districts of Mosul and Telkaif in Ninewa are expected to become functional by March 2020. - Considering communication strategies already implemented to communicate Mosul Dam risks in previous campaigns, it was evident that in addition to the communication in disasters guiding principles, other considerations were also beneficial. - In December 2019, coordination with DoEs in Ninewa, Salahuddin, Baghdad/ Karkh, and Baghdad/ Resafa was secured, and UNICEF received the official letters of nomination of schools (50 schools in Ninewa, 22 in Salahuddin, 15 in Baghdad Karkh, and 15 in Baghdad Resafa). All DoEs, except Ninewa, were ready to start the training in January 2020. Ninewa will follow after the end of the exams and Spring school holiday. - The Dam Safety consultant started his assignment in November 2019. Completed milestones included: design and roll-out of a capacity assessment survey, fields missions that included site visits and meetings with officials in the various dams, submission of two assessment reports: Dokan Dam Gap Analysis Report and Darbandikhan Dam Gap Analysis Report. - Improve Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP) along the Tigris flood plain, to reduce the adverse effects of a Tigris River flood that might be caused by the collapse of the Mosul Dam. During 2019, the workgroup convened more than 12 times and one workshop was conducted. With technical support from MDEPP. - MDEPP team developed a roadmap to mitigate environmental risks to reduce the impact in the case of the Mosul Dam collapse. According to the roadmap, UNDP implemented several activities in partnership with federal and provincial stakeholders in the Governorates of Baghdad, Salahuddin and Ninewa.

1. 153 officials trained on early warning systems 2. 262,048 persons reached with community based awareness raising 3. 1 national, 4 provincial, 1 hospital and 100 school drills completed 4. school preparedness activities in 100 schools completed 5. hospital preparedness activities in hospitals of Baghdad, Ninewa and Salah Al Din completed 6. 200 IRCS volunteers were trained and they set up community based early warning and evacuation teams 7. Contingency plans for 10 CIP facilities including 3 hospitals completed 8. 120 dam managers and officials trained on dam safety and transboundary water negotiations 9. 42 inspectors trained on chemical and toxic pollution control

1. Rapid deployment of preparedness training and tools to operationalize the Governorate preparedness plans. 2. Risk advocacy in the vulnerable communities expanded and strengthened along the Mosul Dam flood path. 3. Drills/simulations conducted to ensure readiness and strengthening emergency preparedness at all levels. 4. Volunteers’ network strengthened for community early warning and evacuation. 5. Emergency preparedness and safety measures of major Dams strengthened. 6. Major facilities protected along the Tigris flood plain to avoid domino impact. 7. Environmental risks of toxic and chemical pollution mitigated to reduce the impacts of Mosul Dam collapse.

A key result achieved during the third quarter of 2020 was the completion of training for 80 nurses and 69 doctors on life skills for emergency life saving. Also with completion of 23 new CMDCs, 42 out of the 47 CDMCs were operationalized/updated. 134 governorate and local officials were trained in emergency preparedness, coordination and response planning. In the last quarter the National Strategy for Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP) was endorsed by the National Security Council (NSC), which is chaired by H.E thePrime Minister. The CIP Strategy was developed by the CIP-Working Group with technical support from UNDP through the Mosul Dam Emergency Preparedness in Iraq project (MDEP). Detailed results by components are as follows:
1. MDEP team worked towards building the basic digital capacities in key institutions at governorate level in order to carryout activities using online platforms. In total 16 institutions are being supported with the digital capacity enhancement. Such capacity is also a requirement for operationalization of the governorate preparedness plans, and can be used by the respective entities in coordinating the government’s response to COVID-19. District and sub-district level CMDCs were activated in Ninewa and Salah Al Din in Q3, 2020. 2. In Q3 awareness and community preparedness materials were prepared by the IRCS and WHO in order to launch a community awareness campaign during the Q4, which is the peak of rain/flood season in Iraq. Community awareness activities were implemented in vulnerable communities, using alternative social media and electronic communication technologies, because carrying out field-based activities was not possible due to the lockdown situation. More than 2 million risk awareness SMS messages were sent via mobile operators Zain and Asia-cell. The messages were geographically targeted covering populated districts along the Tigris river flood path in the governorates of Ninewa, Salah Al Din and Baghdad. 3. After numerous consultations with Federal CD, the CD in Ninewa and Salah Al Din tested the mobile long-range sirens on April 7th. All six mobile long-range sirens operated satisfactorily during the drill. MDEPP responsible party, WHO, is also planning to carryout drills for nurses and hospitals. The hospital drills are planned for November and December 2020. 4. 200 volunteers were selected from vulnerable communities in coordination with the IRCS. however, the training of the first batch of volunteers planned for March 2020 was postponed due to the COVID-19 outbreak. 5. Most of the works under this key activity have already been completed. During the reporting period, the MDEP Dam Safety consultant produced the “National Dam Safety Standards Manual.” 6. During this quarter, the National Security Council (NSC) chaired by the Prime Minister, endorsed the National Strategy for Critical Infrastructure Protection, which was developed by the CIP-WG with technical support from UNDP under the MDEPP. The emergency preparedness and response plans (EPRP) for Al-Dawra Refinery and Al-Dawra Power plants are being drafted by the technical consultant recruited by the project. 7. Several online meetings and consultations were carried out to finalize a plan for mitigation of environmental risks of toxic and chemical pollution to reduce the impact of Mosul Dam collapse. Experts and officials from Ministry of Health and Environment (MoH&E), provincial directorates of environment, and Ministries of Industry and Oil, which operate many chemical facilities participated in three consultation meeting organized remotely during this quarter.
